name: Improve the efficiency and scalability of public goods funding through deployment of new products, systems, and financial instruments
description:
Our mission is to massively improve the efficiency and scalability of public goods funding through deployment of new products, systems, and financial instruments. We are looking for solutions that touch the real world - build a product that helps better allocate resources, a platform to aggregate funding, or a new financial / legal innovation that you can deploy as a system for others to use.  We also want to see existing primitives and tools combined in new ways, attached to real-life use cases

Inspiration:

  • A reverse auction house where ecosystems / funders can put bounties against technology they want to see in the world

  • A platform to better aggregate evaluations of project impact and submit on-chain via an attestation (or bespoke) service

  • On-chain public goods credit or convertible equity instruments

  • Link Allo protocol to Govrn / coordinape type evaluation systems
acceptanceCriteria:
1. Project Description

  • The name and summary of the project

  • Names/pseudonyms of team members and contact info (e.g., GitHub handle, email address, or other)

  • How the project uses to IPFS and/or Filecoin and/or decentralized storage services that build on top of either with example links to where in code those technologies are used.

2. Link to the publicly visible source code repository

  • Include a link to the working demo or provide a testing guide

3. Showcase

  • 2-3 minute video that presents the idea, including a brief demo that demonstrates the use of IPFS and/or Filecoin or anything that builds on top of them

  • If applicable, select the appropriate track when submitting the project.

NOTE:

  • Submitting the same project across multiple hackathons will lead to disqualification

  • Only projects or features (preferably in separate branch) built specifically for the respective hackathon will be considered for prizes

  • Broken links may disqualify the project from the judging process.

  • Using an IPFS HTTP gateway does not count as building on top of IPFS. Exclusively basing your submission on that does not make you eligible for prizes.

    Judging

  • Design: Is it easy to use? Does the visual design delight you? If targeting developers, is the experience smooth and intuitive?

  • Novelty/Originality: Does it have unique and novel features or combine features of other products or services in a unique and novel way?

  • Technical Accomplishment: Is the code elegant, clean, and technically interesting? Is the project complete? Does the project interact with IPFS/Filecoin under-the-hood (i.e., more than simply retrieve a CID from a gateway)?

  • Potential Impact: Does it fill a gap in the universe, and have the potential to be used frequently by a large, growing and diverse audience or market?

  • Creativity/Fun/Wow-Factor: Is it creative and put a smile on people’s faces?

Submissions will be rated with decimal numbers between 1 (worst) - 5 (best) per category (max score: 25) by each judge. The final score is the average of all voting judges. If a project scores low, we reserve the right not to award prizes, even if it was the only project submitted to a given track.

winners.name: Footprint
winners.description: A decentralized carbon footprint calculator for Gitcoin Grants participants, measuring the environmental impact of their activities to provide more transparency and enable direct offsetting through tokenized carbon credits.

winners.name: voicedeck
winners.description: In this hackathon, we created code enabling web2 nonprofits to convert their past database of impact into hypercerts on Goerli. We also made a Figma design for customers to purchase these impact certs as gift cards commemorating special occasions.

winners.name: AutoGreenGrants

AutoGreenGrants is an innovative grants platform designed to automate the process of:

- Distributing payouts to participants.
- Purchasing carbon credits while providing attestation to participants.

Want to be part of the solution? Build the next generation of public goods funding infrastructure during this hackathon!

name: Best integration between co2.storage and hypercerts for impact certification
description:
Co2.storage (soon to be transform.storage!) is a tool for showing end-to-end decision making built for proving impact in a web3 context. It does this by modeling decisions as a compute graphs anchored in content addressed types. For this challenge, build a tool that allows users to provide evidence of their impact stored on co2.storage and mint a hypercert which references it. See the co2.storage docs under resources for more information.

The hypercerts integration is co2.storage with hypercerts.xyz

description: Build a interface for using Basic Attention Token (BAT) to support public goods. Crypto and DeFi are hard to use and the $330 billion digital advertising industry is failing users, publishers and advertisers. With Basic Attention Token and Brave we want to take Crypto to the next 1B users and solve the endemic inefficiencies and privacy violations hobbling the digital ad industry.

name: Mobile First Verified Credential Application with Lit
description:
Mobile first verified credentials with Lit encrypted backups stored on dweb. Using programmable key pair (PKP) for auth.

Build a mobile first verified credential application with Lit to encrypt backups stored on the decentralized web. Using programmable key pair (PKP) for auth.

The flow of the application may look like logging in with Google (through Lit's Programmable Key Pair connection) to pull data from Filecoin, decrypt the data and then store locally on the new device.
acceptanceCriteria:
• Must utilize Lit's encryption and Programmable Key Pairs.

  • UI/UX is top priority!

  • Output should include a demo and documentation of how it utilizes Lit.

name: Build the best front end for a grants app that uses Allo protocol to run grants rounds on Celo
description: Allo Protocol is an open-source protocol that enables groups to efficiently and transparently allocate pooled capital. Celo is the carbon-negative, mobile-first, EVM-compatible Layer 1 blockchain with a community proposal to become an L2 on Ethereum in the future. Allo protocol is now deployed on Celo testnet and we are asking you to hack on different front ends to create a grants app on Celo that utilizes the Allo protocol smart contracts.
acceptanceCriteria:
• Must be deployed on Celo testnet, must use Allo protocol 

  • Please note: if there are less than 5 projects, then no bounty will be awarded for this challenge statement.

name: Build the best Integrations on top of the GoodDollar Protocol to Support UBI Funding and Public Goods
description:
G$ tokens are real tokens held by 500,000+ people around the globe for both online and offline use. Opportunities abound to build upon this infrastructure - GoodDollar enables you to leverage our technical, financial, and active community resources. The GoodDollar protocol facilitates direct payments to individuals, allowing for targeted support through GoodDollar UBI.

Explore the provided GoodDollar challenges or propose your own. Team up and start building!

And don't forget to join the GoodDollar Hackers Group for support!


Challenge Ideas:

1. Perpetual Quadratic Funding Rounds Using Allo and G$ Supertoken
Imagine if users could continually vote for projects by continuously streaming funds to them, eliminating the need to return and vote each round. Each round would calculate the pool and votes streamed during that period. GoodDollar, as a native superfluid token on Celo, can be extended with Allo functionality to create a Superapp and develop a user interface for project support. Additionally, GoodDollar's unique anti-sybil identity can be employed to prevent double voting in quadratic funding. Consider submitting your work to the Celo Allo UI challenge and the Best Public Good Funding challenge as well.

Acceptance Criteria:

  • Utilize G$ streams to bolster projects.

  • Utilize G$ Identity to prevent double voting.

  • Enable voting based on round streams.

  • Create a UI to facilitate project support.

  • Develop a Superapp based on Allo and quadratic funding.

  • Adhere to the general acceptance criteria (outlined below).

2. Simplified GoodCollective Pool Creation
GoodCollective offers a new approach to UBI as a service - direct, automatic payments to specific individuals based on actions. While the app for supporting these pools is in progress, we lack an interface for creating new pools.

Acceptance Criteria:

  • Design a straightforward interface for creating GoodCollective pools.

  • Build on the existing code base.

  • Allow customization of pool parameters as per GoodCollective smart contracts.

  • Store pool descriptions and static attributes as JSON on IPFS.

  • Meet the general acceptance criteria (see below).

3. Worldcoin Identity Integration
Worldcoin introduces a more secure sybil resistance identity compared to GoodDollar's face verification approach. Extend the GoodDollar app and protocol to accommodate Worldcoin IDs. For example, G$ verified members who link their Worldcoin IDs could receive an extra 20% daily UBI upon payment of a 10 Worldcoin token registration fee.

Acceptance Criteria:

  • Develop an easy-to-use UI for connecting a Worldcoin ID.

  • Create a smart contract registry for unique Worldcoin ID proofs, linkable to G$ verified accounts.

  • Modify the UBIScheme contract to support Worldcoin IDs.

  • Meet the general acceptance criteria (see below)
acceptanceCriteria:
All summations must also adhere to these criteria. A repository containing the code for review should include the following information in the readme.md:

Project Description:

  • The name and summary of the project

  • Names/pseudonyms of team members and their contact information (e.g., GitHub handle, email address, or other)

  • How the project is built on top of GoodDollar

Showcase:

  • A link to the publicly visible working demo, presented in a video with a maximum duration of 5 minutes

  • A testing guide

This version maintains your content while refining the grammar for better clarity and correctness.
rewardDescription:
GoodDollar will be supporting 2,000 USDC + 1,000,000 G$ in rewards for teams that build on GoodDollar

Prizes will be divided and awarded across teams that submit viable solutions, and top teams will be invited to participate to continue their build out via the GoodDollar <> Celo Prosperity Program.

name: Best Novel Grants App Prototype
description:
Grants have become one of the primary ways in which ecosystems in web3 grow and increase adoption. These grants programs can range in size, from small programs issuing $5,000 grants, to larger programs that release millions of dollars every quarter. Regardless of size, the tooling for running these programs onchain is way behind the market for funds to be distributed: most web3 grants programs out there are run on Notion, Airtable, and a multi-sig wallet.

Allo is a protocol for efficiently and transparently allocating resources onchain. It empowers groups of all sizes to decide how they want to allocate funding. It leverages the years of experience Gitcoin earned, running 18 rounds of its Quadratic Funding (QF) grants program, Gitcoin Grants.

A core piece of Allo Protocol is the ability to write smart contracts that manage who is eligible to receive funding from a pool and how those funds are distributed (called an allocation strategy). This is useful for building novel ways of allocating and distributing grants:

  • Use donation-to-vote QF to distribute lump-sum grants (like Gitcoin does)

  • Use Hats Protocol to create and manage a grants committee

  • Distribute funds as a milestone-based payment or a Sablier stream

And many more interesting ways we hope you’ll think of that we can’t. 

We challenge you to build an application that could power a grants program and runs on Allo Protocol. The particulars of the program are up to you! The challenge is to build a prototype for something that a program manager could use to start distributing grants in a novel way.
acceptanceCriteria:
1. Project Description

  • The name and summary of the project

  • Names/pseudonyms of team members and contact info (e.g., GitHub handle, email address, or other)

  • How the project uses Allo


2. Link to the publicly visible source code repository

  • Include a link to the working demo and the open-source repository on Github

3. Showcase

  • 2-3 minute explainer video that presents the application. The video should be aimed at grants program managers and showcases how your app will help them distribute their grant funding

4. Judging

  • Design and UX: Is it visually appealing and easy to use?

  • Originality: Does it have unique and novel features or combine features of other products or services in a unique and novel way?

  • Technical Accomplishment: Is the code elegant, clean, and technically interesting? Is the project complete? Does the project interact with Allo Protocol under-the-hood?

  • Potential Utility: Does the project fill a need that grant program managers have? Does it have the potential to be used by grant program managers?

Submissions will be rated with decimal numbers between 1 (worst) - 5 (best) per category (max score: 25) by each judge. The final score is the average of all voting judges. If a project scores low, we reserve the right not to award prizes, even if it was the only project submitted to a given track.

name: Best Use of the Project Registry
description:
Grants have become one of the primary ways in which ecosystems in web3 grow and increase adoption. These grants programs can range in size, from small programs issuing $5,000 grants, to larger programs that release millions of dollars every quarter. Regardless of size, the tooling for running these programs onchain is way behind the market for funds to be distributed: most web3 grants programs out there are run on Notion, Airtable, and a multi-sig wallet.

Allo is a protocol for efficiently and transparently allocating resources onchain. It empowers groups of all sizes to decide how they want to allocate funding. It leverages the years of experience Gitcoin earned, running 18 rounds of its Quadratic Funding (QF) grants program, Gitcoin Grants.

One core piece of Allo Protocol is the project registry: a universal, onchain registry of projects that distribute and/or receive funds. A key problem to be solved for grants programs is evaluating projects and determining which are good and likely to deliver on their grant. The registry allows projects to earn reputation through attestations, soul bound tokens, and many other means.

We challenge you to build an application that leverages the project registry in a compelling way. This could be (but is not limited to):

  • Building ways for projects to be curated using token staking, voting, or something else

  • Making project activity and reputation visible to program managers (the funding they’ve received, attestations they’ve received, etc)

  • An analysis tool to see how a pool of funding is distributed

These are just meant as ideas to get you started!There are many more interesting ways you can use the project registry.
acceptanceCriteria:
1. Project Description

  • The name and summary of the project

  • Names/pseudonyms of team members and contact info (e.g., GitHub handle, email address, or other)

  • How the project uses Allo and the project registry

2. Link to the publicly visible source code repository

  • Include a link to the working demo and the open-source repository on Github

3. Showcase

  • 2-3 minute explainer video that presents the application. What problem does it solve? How does it solve that problem?

4. Judging

  • Design and UX: Is it visually appealing and easy to use?

  • Originality: Does it have unique and novel features or combine features of other products or services in a unique and novel way?

  • Technical Accomplishment: Is the code elegant, clean, and technically interesting? Is the project complete? Does the project interact with Allo Protocol under-the-hood?

  • Potential Utility: Does the project fill a need that grant program managers have? Does it have the potential to be used by grant program managers?

Submissions will be rated with decimal numbers between 1 (worst) - 5 (best) per category (max score: 25) by each judge. The final score is the average of all voting judges. If a project scores low, we reserve the right not to award prizes, even if it was the only project submitted to a given track.

name: Best Review and Evaluation Tool
description:
Grants have become one of the primary ways in which ecosystems in web3 grow and increase adoption. These grants programs can range in size, from small programs issuing $5,000 grants, to larger programs that release millions of dollars every quarter. Regardless of size, the tooling for running these programs onchain is way behind the market for funds to be distributed: most web3 grants programs out there are run on Notion, Airtable, and a multi-sig wallet.

Allo is a protocol for efficiently and transparently allocating resources onchain. It empowers groups of all sizes to decide how they want to allocate funding. It leverages the years of experience Gitcoin earned, running 18 rounds of its Quadratic Funding (QF) grants program, Gitcoin Grants.

One of the key goals of Allo is to make the flow of funds auditable and transparent. This will help evaluate how a pool of funds is distributed and to show where projects are receiving their funding. 

We challenge you to build an application (front end, dashboard, etc) that showcases how funds flow through Allo. Between the project registry and the pool manager (Allo.sol), there are many ways you could build tools for monitoring the flow of funds:

  • A “project profile” application that showcases how much funding a project has received and where that funding has come from (think Open Startup but for grant recipients)

  • Similarly, a “pool profile” tool that shows how pools of funds are distributed on Allo

  • A block-explorer like application that makes it easy to navigate around the data on Allo (pools, projects, strategies, etc)

  • An analytics tool that allows program managers to easily do quality assurance on QF rounds

These are just meant as ideas to get you started! There are many more interesting ways you can use the data generated by Allo.
acceptanceCriteria:
1. Project Description

  • The name and summary of the project

  • Names/pseudonyms of team members and contact info (e.g., GitHub handle, email address, or other)

  • How the project uses Allo

2. Link to the publicly visible source code repository

  • Include a link to the working demo and the open-source repository on Github

3. Showcase

  • 2-3 minute explainer video that presents the application.

4. Judging

  • Design and UX: Is it visually appealing and easy to use?

  • Originality: Does it have unique and novel features or combine features of other products or services in a unique and novel way?

  • Technical Accomplishment: Is the code elegant, clean, and technically interesting? Is the project complete? Does the project interact with Allo Protocol under-the-hood?

  • Potential Utility: Does the project fill a need that grant program managers have? Does it have the potential to be used by grant program managers?

Submissions will be rated with decimal numbers between 1 (worst) - 5 (best) per category (max score: 25) by each judge. The final score is the average of all voting judges. If a project scores low, we reserve the right not to award prizes, even if it was the only project submitted to a given track.

winners.name: allo exploreR
winners.description: An awesome tool to visualise Allo Protocol Data in R+Shiny

name: Leverage the Endaoment Protocol data to make a visualization of web3 impact
description:
Unlock the potential of web3's impact through a captivating visualization, tapping into the vast array of digital donation data at your fingertips with Endaoment.

Our GraphQL Subgraph makes it easy to query a broad range of data from the largest rolodex of payment endpoints for nonprofits – 7,880+ global orgs and counting. Pull platform statistics, surface contract addresses, and format donation transactions with straightforward GraphQL. Capturing activity with Dune Dashboards are also welcome.

Check out our Hack4Impact Toolkit for things we like, links and to learn more.

Potential examples of use:

  • The visualization could live on a site like “stats.endaoment.org”.

  • Featured as an independent survey of web3 impact.

  • Included in our Impact Report for 2023 Giving Season

  • Shared on endaoment.org and socials.

Potential Insights, but use your creativity:

  • Track the growth trajectory of crypto-philanthropy.

  • Discover top contributing organizations.

  • Visualize the flow of donations through contract interactions.

Opportunity:

Web3 is revolutionizing the philanthropic landscape, but how can we better express genuine impact? Highlight the tangible change web3 brings to philanthropy. How could the visualization become a reference to express where web3 impact currently is and where it could go?
acceptanceCriteria:
1. Project Description

  • The name and summary of the project

  • Names/pseudonyms of team members and contact info (e.g., GitHub handle, email address, or other)

  • How the project uses the Endaoment subgraph or protocol data

2. Link to the publicly visible source code repository

  • Include a link to the working demo or provide a testing guide

3. Showcase

  • 2-3 minute video that presents the idea, including a brief demo that demonstrates the use of Endaoment subgraph or protocol data. If applicable, select the appropriate track when submitting the project.

resources.description: Funding Public Good x Endaoment Hack4Impact Tool Kit

name: Best integration with the Endaoment protocol
description: Our new developer tools allow you to programmatically and seamlessly integrate giving into any application or website. Whether you're inspired to streamline crypto-philanthropy donations or enhance their reach, we're excited to see how you'll redefine the use of our protocol. Shape the future of web3 giving. Check out our Hack4Impact Toolkit for ideas we like, links, and to learn more.
acceptanceCriteria:
1. Project Description

  • The name and summary of the project

  • Names/pseudonyms of team members and contact info (e.g., GitHub handle, email address, or other)

  • How the project implements the Endaoment protocol

2. Link to the publicly visible source code repository

  • Include a link to the working demo or provide a testing guide

3. Showcase

  • 2-3 minute video that presents the idea, including a brief demo that demonstrates the implementation of the Endaoment protocol. If applicable, select the appropriate track when submitting the project.

resources.description: Funding Public Good x Endaoment Hack4Impact Tool Kit

name: Craft an innovative tool or interface focused on tracking and analyzing the activities and metrics of Octant public data, including Ethereum Validators public data, smart contracts on-chain data, Octant Subgraph, etc.
description:
Description:

Ethereum validators play a pivotal role in maintaining the integrity and functionality of the network. With Octant's substantial stake and vast validator network, we aim to provide the community with a detailed lens into their operations. The goal is to devise a tool that can be utilized broadly across Ethereum Validators, offering insights into performance metrics, proposing validator optimizations, and enhancing the transparency and understanding of the network's backbone.

The smart contracts powering Octant also produce public data that can be visualized to provide important insights to the community about the state of the system, statistics, etc.

Criteria & Project Description

  • Specify the project's name and a concise summary.

  • Introduce names/pseudonyms of team members, accompanied by contact details (e.g., GitHub handle, email address).

  • Illustrate how the project engages with Ethereum validator data or other Octant public data, emphasizing its relevance to Octant's vast validator network and Octant community.

Source Code & Demo

  • Link to the open-source code repository.

  • Offer a link to a live demonstration or supply a thorough testing guide.

Showcase

  • Produce a 2-3 minute video presenting the project. This should include a demo highlighting the platform's efficacy in interpreting and visualizing Ethereum validator data, especially concerning Octant's validators, or/and other available Octant public data.

  • If there are multiple submission tracks, please choose the most appropriate one when submitting the project.

Extra Bonus:

  • Between the Funding The Commons Hackathon and Residency, if any project is selected to be used by the Octant team, an additional 5k USD reward will be given.
acceptanceCriteria: How does your tool redefine the way we perceive and understand Ethereum validators? How do you visualize useful information about Octant on-chain acitivity? What unique insights or features does it bring, particularly in relation to Octant's extensive validator network or other Octant public data?

winners.name: Datanudge
winners.description: Using data to nudge user behavior to increase public goods funding.

name: Mint NFTs for Drips supporters
description:
Write a smart contract that mints an NFT and transfers it to the funder of a Drips project or Drip List. The NFT should be issued as soon as the funder starts supporting a project with their Drip List, and revoked or destroyed when they stop supporting.

Ideally, the NFT metadta (like image) is customizable by the project owner
acceptanceCriteria:
1. Project Description

The name and summary of the project

Names/pseudonyms of team members and contact info (e.g., GitHub handle, email address, or other)

2. Link to the publicly visible source code repository

Include a link to the working demo or provide a testing guide

3. Showcase

2-3 minute video that presents the idea

winners.name: Drips Campaign Driver
winners.description: A Drips Driver that mints NFTs for users based on their support of Drips accounts. Generates metadata on-chain and supports customisation by the account being supported.

name: Integrate Drips with Hypercerts
description: Find new & creative ways to integrate Drips with Hypercerts, with the goal to enhance the experience of funding public goods either for the funder of the recipient.
acceptanceCriteria:
1. Project Description

The name and summary of the project

Names/pseudonyms of team members and contact info (e.g., GitHub handle, email address, or other)

2. Link to the publicly visible source code repository

Include a link to the working demo or provide a testing guide

3. Showcase

2-3 minute video that presents the idea

name: Expanding Decentralized Identities
description:
The Expanding Decentralized Identities is a bounty sponsored by the Ethereum Name Service Public Goods working group.

The Ethereum Name Service protocol received early grant funding from the Ethereum Foundation. With this history, supporting new ideas, innovative projects, and builders is vital.

This challenge focuses on the theme of Expanding Decentralized Identities. For this challenge, we are looking for novel technical implementations that expand how we currently store, use, and interact with our digital identities on the blockchain.

What we are looking For

Projects will abide by the theme outlined in the challenge description and shall include an implementation of one of the following technical specifications:

  1. ERC-3668: CCIP READ

  2. ERC-4337 or other Account Abstraction primitive.

Because this is a Public Goods bounty, we are not solely interested in implementations that leverage ENS but are open to all projects that meet the acceptance criteria and feel that they meet the ethos of this challenge.
acceptanceCriteria:
1. Project Description

  • The name and summary of the project

  • Names/pseudonyms of team members and contact info (e.g., GitHub handle, email address, or other)

  • Clearly explain how the project expands on how we currently store, use, and interact with our digital identities using CCIP Read or any Account Abstraction primitive.

2. Link to the publicly visible source code repository

  • Must include a link to the working demo or provide a testing guide. Projects must have this criterion to be scored or rated.

3. Showcase

  • 2-3 minute video that presents the idea, including a brief demo on what this implementation unlocks for decentralized identities. This should be a working demo, not a presentation of conceptualized ideas.
rewardDescription: This prize pool is not guaranteed. Projects that do no meet the Acceptance Criteria will not be scored.

winners.name: ZK Passport
winners.description: Key Passport allows you to manage your identity, attestations, proofs or any kind keys using your Ethereum account. It uses Metamask Snaps as a way to deterministically generate keys based on your existing account that acts as the recovery root.
